body.p:
I have a few moments before
going home to prepare for the Sabbath and devote
it to you. Your last letter dated in Decr.
needs no reply now, for everything is changed
by the death of our late friend Mr Touro.
Poor good old ?, he had noble impulses
but? his great misfortune was in his want
of education. Some of his notions were
good and to the extent that I can I
will carry them out, as I have done
thus far. I presume I may not be able
to leave here before July next, and
his positive and respected instructions
to different persons, were that after his
death everything relating to all the
last offices to be performed should
be directed and attended to by me
in person, I shall detain his
remains until I am read to start
from here, and until then I shall
make no final arrangements for
his burial in New Port. In accordance
with his dislike to ostentatious funer
als, the interment here was attended
only by those who chose to come without
the slightest invitation. The children of
three Christian orphans asylums

followed the hearse and the Firemens
Charitable Association, the veterans
of 14 & 15 also attended. The hearse I ordered
to be perfectly plain—one horse. The
coffin—metal covered with black cloth. Genl.
Plafrey desired to call out the military
but we prefered to have no display
and particularly no music, nevertheless
the number of citizens was immense
and a general gloom was evident
The stores on the same square where
he resided were closed. Beyond the
spontaneous actions of the citizens, it
was an ordinary Jewish funeral with
the exception that I had those large
doors of the Synagogue opened while
the funeral passed.

He had been unconscious for some
days before he died. When he died
(Gutheim) the minister the Doctor the Shamas
and myself were with him, and until
the last breath we repeated together the
usual verses. I closed his eyes—

Now Mr Leeser I have made up my mind
to one thing and that is to conduct the
affair at New Port, as similarly to what
I did here—the only thing that may
induce me to alt deviate will be in
case the public civil authorities of that

city or Boston, should wish to make
any demonstrations of respect, then
I shall feel it a duty to forego all
private considerations for the object
of bringing credit to Israel in the world.
Do not misunderstand me, I have no
idea of the remains leaving my or other
Jewish hands, it must be a Jewish funeral
and nothing else, but perhaps I might have
a service in the synagogue.

I shall see that you take some part in
the ceremonies, if any take place, but I
shall only study the general good effect
to be produced, in selecting ministers to
officiate on the occasion. Individual
preferences, nay the most friendly attach
ments must not be regarded, when an
opportunity offers to elevate the nation
in the eye of those who surround us—
you know we have always dispensed
with the Hakaforth here in New Orleans
and as it is only a minhag I should like
to omit it in New Port if possible. The
more quiet and the less singing at a funeral
the more imposing it will ever be. Many
congregations & societies have offered their services
in which those of the Hazans have been
included. On this occasion I shall not
study or regard official offers, to interfere

with the great object in view. I know
some will claim preferences because they
are Portuguese or are in the Will or
any other special plea. Some may
say you are no longer a Minister. I shall
only strive to serve the common cause
and care little for the pleasure or displeasure
of any but such as can understand
my own feelings. I shall probably
inform the Jewish public through the
Occident, as to the time &c of the interment.

You may depend I have no leisure
time. You can not imagine the disgusting
communications that come to shepherd
from some of our societies, giving recitals
of congregational differences jealousies &c. I
have to blush frequently, and try to put
the best face on it. The main labor now
devolves on me, and I am Repl? hard
at work all day!

Oh my dear friend if you knew how I
had to work to get that Will made, and how
I strive to serve you, you would pity me. Alas
it was not altogether what I wanted yet I am
thankful to God that ever if I injured myself
I got the most of what I asked for Israel—
arguments, charges and counter-charges in
the sums of Institutions till my heart sickened
I appeared calm but indeed was almost crazy
ever dreading that nothing would be achieved in
the end. The list of Jewish Institutions I made up
as well as I could. I had dreadful hard work to raise
your Education Society from 10 to 20,000
